46:59 Caption: There was plenty of entertainment during the first 45 minutes. Hopefully more of the same in the second half. Manchester Utd enjoyed superiority over the opposition in that first 45 minutes. The home side have dominated the possession and midfield so far. The visitors have spent most of their time defending and waiting for the right moment to launch counter-attacks.

    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
On a lively afternoon at Old Trafford, Manchester United showcased their dominance in a Premier League match against Leicester City, securing a commanding 4-1 victory. The match saw Manchester United's clinical finishing and solid defensive performance coupled with Leicester’s struggles to find form despite a late consolation goal. Here's a detailed description of the game's proceedings.

The match kicked off with Manchester United starting on the front foot. Almost immediately, incidents of the ball going out of play marked the first few minutes, showing both sides’ attempts to assert their presence on the pitch. A throw-in by Manchester United was followed closely by another ball going out of play, highlighting early misplaced passes and uneasy nerves. As the clock ticked past the second minute, Leicester committed a foul, and though their subsequent indirect free-kick did not result in any meaningful effort, it set a pattern that would be prevalent in the match.

Manchester United’s first significant attempt came in the fourth minute when Leicester defenders had to make a clearance following a threat from the hosts. Shortly after, Leicester committed another foul, leading to a Manchester United free-kick. Several throw-ins followed, a characteristic of a match where both teams were frequently halting play through interceptive measures.

An early sign of United’s intention came from a shot off target in the third minute, indicating their attacking intent. Minutes later, even though Leicester's defenders managed to clear a corner, the Red Devils soon returned with another effort. By the ninth minute, Christian Fuchs of Leicester had a well-executed shot blocked, reflecting Leicester’s sporadic threats.

Manchester United’s first breakthrough came from a set piece. After several plays of throw-ins and free-kicks, Daley Blind delivered a splendid corner that found Chris Smalling, who headed the ball into the net in the 21st minute to make it 1-0. This was a critical moment, highlighting United’s efficiency in capitalizing on set pieces.

Leicester attempted to respond quickly, but their attempts were met with deft defending from United. Another sequence of play was dominated by throw-ins and corner kicks for both sides, underscoring the numerous disruptions and their effects on fluid gameplay.

Continued pressure from Manchester culminated into a second goal. Jesse Lingard provided a pass to Juan Mata on the edge of the box, who then netted a precise shot into the left side of the goal in the 36th minute. This goal amplified United’s growing confidence and ability to breach Leicester’s defenses.

Minutes later, another corner led to Marcus Rashford’s goal, marking Manchester United’s third of the day. Juan Mata turned provider by setting up Rashford for a simple, close-range finish in the 39th minute. This goal epitomized United’s dominance and clinical finishing in front of goal.

Right before the halftime whistle, another corner from United saw Paul Pogba rise above defenders to head home their fourth goal. Daley Blind’s consistent quality deliveries from corners were rewarded once again as Pogba found the back of the net, making it 4-0. The first half concluded, reflecting United’s complete control and Leicester’s inefficacy in defense.

As the second half commenced, Leicester’s manager Claudio Ranieri made crucial substitutions to restore some dignity for his team. Two early changes were made: Demarai Gray replaced Jamie Vardy, and Andy King came in for Riyad Mahrez, indicating a strategic attempt to drive more energy and creativity into Leicester’s gameplay.

Despite these changes, the initial stages of the second half were characterized by disrupted play – several throw-ins and free-kicks were evident again. Robert Huth’s tackle on a United player resulted in a yellow card just four minutes into the half, showcasing a bit of Leicester’s frustration.

Manchester United continued to threaten, with Zlatan Ibrahimovic missing a header just wide and another Manchester attempt forcing Ron-Robert Zieler to act decisively. Leicester sporadically managed to orchestrate their own plays, though they often ended with the ball going out or United intercepting efficiently.

Leicester’s later attempts bore some fruit when Demarai Gray produced a moment of brilliance, scoring a spectacular goal in the 58th minute with a venomous shot from around 21 meters out. This reduced the deficit to 4-1 and gave Leicester a glimmer of hope. The team’s visible morale boost led to a few more attempts, though most were dealt with adequately by United’s defense.

United made strategic substitutions to manage the game’s remaining time – Michael Carrick came in to shore up midfield stability. Juan Mata, who had a stellar performance, gave way for Ashley Young in the final stages. Wayne Rooney also entered the fray, replacing Marcus Rashford.

In the game’s dying moments, United maintained possession and continued to thwart any last-minute pushes by Leicester. Few thrilling moments were thereafter, with Manchester United content to see out their substantial lead and Leicester unable to mount significant pressure.

The attendance of 75,256 watched as the referee blew the final whistle, bringing an end to a match where Manchester United asserted significant dominance. With goals from Smalling, Mata, Rashford, and Pogba, United showed their class and efficiency, especially in set-piece situations. Leicester, despite some spirited efforts post-half-time, couldn’t overturn the severe deficit.

This victory was a testament to Manchester United’s tactical proficiency, defensive solidity, and attacking potency. Leicester’s struggles underscored their defensive frailties and the need for improved execution at both ends. The lively match, filled with numerous fouls, throw-ins, and a handful of quality goals, provided an engaging narrative reflecting United’s superiority and Leicester’s valiant but insufficient attempts at a comeback.
